name: Tenant Defending Against Deregulation Claim
description: A tenant in a rent-stabilized building is being told by their landlord that the apartment was deregulated via high-rent vacancy. The tenant wants to know if they can challenge this.

user_input.situation: My landlord is claiming my apartment was deregulated in 2010 when the rent hit $2,500. They're trying to evict me for non-payment of $2,200/month rent, but I think the apartment should still be rent-stabilized. The building was built before 1974 and has more than 6 units. I've been here since 2015 and never got any paperwork about deregulation.
evidence_i_have: No rent stabilization rider in my lease
DHCR registration history showing inconsistent records

key_evidence_gaps: Proof of rent at time of alleged deregulation

strong_points: Pre-1974 building establishes rent stabilization eligibility
Missing rent stabilization rider violates landlord's notice requirement
Inconsistent DHCR records undermine deregulation claim (like 756 Liberty)
gaps_to_address: Request landlord's IAI documentation through discovery
Document the rent history for prior tenants

expected_next_steps: File answer to non-payment petition asserting rent stabilization defense
Demand discovery for IAI documentation, DHCR registrations, prior leases
Request that landlord prove lawful deregulation with documentation

key_lessons: Landlord bears burden of proving lawful deregulation
IAI claims require contemporaneous documentation (invoices, receipts)
Rent stabilization rider must be provided to first tenant after deregulation
Conflicting DHCR registrations undermine landlord's case
Court can look beyond 4-year lookback period to determine regulatory status
